header.title: The New Writings of Rav Ashlag: Article on World Peace Part 20

central_thesis: True individual satisfaction and collective world peace are unattainable under the inherent human 'desire to receive for oneself,' which perpetuates an imbalance of suffering over pleasure. Lasting peace and well-being necessitate a fundamental transformation of human nature from self-serving reception to altruistic bestowal, reflecting a profound shift in consciousness.

structure_content.chapter_title: Interdependence of Peace and Societal Dysfunction
structure_content.summary: This initial section establishes that global peace and national peace are inextricably linked, meaning one cannot exist without the other. It argues that even those seemingly 'satisfied' within a nation, particularly the 'energetic and clever,' live in a state of underlying insecurity due to widespread conflict. The text observes that influential minorities, such as 'war experts and weapon suppliers,' often perpetuate a societal predisposition towards 'wars and bloodshed,' highlighting a pervasive collective inclination towards conflict.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Deficit of Pleasure and the 'Desire to Receive'
structure_content.summary: The core philosophical problem is identified as the human 'desire to receive for oneself,' defined as the pursuit of all forms of 'pleasure,' from material possessions to mental gratification. Through a stark mathematical analogy, the author claims that the 'troubles' experienced in life vastly outweigh its 'pleasure' (e.g., 77 times more, or 60% suffering without reward). This analysis demonstrates that a life governed by the 'desire to receive' inherently results in a net deficit of reward, making existence ultimately unfulfilling from a purely egoistic perspective.

The text presents the only viable solution: a profound, non-psychological transformation of human nature from the 'desire to receive for oneself' to the 'desire to share with others.' This shift is portrayed as the 'whole point of difficulty and heaviness' in human existence. It posits that universal understanding of this principle would lead to the adoption of a 'lifestyle of the last generation,' where individuals, driven by enlightened self-preservation, would willingly 'give everything they possess' to ensure collective safety and foster peace, thereby correcting the inherent imbalance caused by the self-serving will.

key_concepts.term: Desire to Receive for Oneself (Ratzon L'kabel)
key_concepts.definition: The fundamental, egoistic drive of human nature, encompassing all forms of seeking pleasure, gratification, and self-enrichment. According to the author, this intrinsic will is the root cause of individual suffering, dissatisfaction, and global conflict due to its inherent imbalance, where 'trouble' invariably outweighs 'pleasure.'

key_concepts.term: Desire to Share with Others (Ratzon L'hashpia)
key_concepts.definition: The transformed and altruistic aspect of human nature, a shift from self-serving reception to selfless bestowal. This is presented as the essential spiritual correction (Tikkun) required to overcome the deficit of pleasure and achieve true, lasting satisfaction and peace, both individually and collectively. It is a profound, non-psychological reorientation of one's core being.

key_concepts.term: Interdependence of World Peace and Country Peace
key_concepts.definition: The principle that the state of global tranquility directly impacts and determines the internal peace and security of any given nation and its inhabitants. No individual or society can achieve true safety or satisfaction while a lack of peace persists globally, highlighting a unified field of human well-being.

A conceptual societal paradigm proposed as the ideal state following the transformation from the 'desire to receive' to the 'desire to share.' In this state, individuals, having understood the futility of egoistic pursuit, willingly contribute to the collective good out of a wise understanding of mutual self-preservation, leading to universal peace and satisfaction.

A numerical assertion that, under the condition of the 'desire to receive,' human life is characterized by a disproportionate amount of suffering ('trouble') compared to pleasure. The author quantitatively suggests that a significant percentage of human suffering is 'without any reward,' underscoring the inherent inefficiency and dissatisfaction of an ego-driven existence.

practical_system.description: The 'practical system' described is not a series of rituals or magical operations in the typical occult sense, but rather a profound process of internal, conscious transformation. It operates on the principle that true individual and collective well-being can only manifest through a fundamental shift in one's core intent: from egoistic 'desire to receive' to altruistic 'desire to share.' This transformation is achieved through intellectual and spiritual 'understanding,' leading to a new 'lifestyle' where self-preservation is wisely redirected to foster collective bestowal. The 'operative' side involves persistent self-assessment against the pleasure/trouble metric and the conscious cultivation of an outward-focused, giving mentality as the path to genuine internal satisfaction and external peace. The 'magic' here is the alchemical transformation of human nature itself.
tools: Understanding and awareness of the underlying principles of the 'desire to receive' and 'desire to share.'
Critical self-assessment of personal motivations and the resulting balance of pleasure and suffering.
Engaging with the philosophical and mathematical arguments presented to reinforce the necessity of transformation.
Study of Rav Ashlag's writings and related Kabbalistic texts for deeper insight and guidance.
rituals: Daily self-reflection and contemplation on the balance of receiving versus sharing in one's actions.
Conscious efforts to transform self-serving intentions into altruistic ones in all interactions.
Study and meditative absorption of Kabbalistic principles, particularly those concerning bestowal and reception.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is fundamentally significant to Qabalistic studies, particularly the teachings of Rav Yehuda Ashlag, known for his unique interpretation of Lurianic Kabbalah that emphasizes the correction of the 'will to receive' (Ratzon L'kabel) into the 'will to bestow' (Ratzon L'hashpia) as the primary spiritual work. It translates abstract metaphysical concepts into a concrete ethical and sociological imperative for achieving world peace. The article's critique of self-serving existence and its mathematical demonstration of inherent suffering resonate with the esoteric concept of the 'breaking of the vessels' (Shevirat HaKelim) and the subsequent need for spiritual correction (Tikkun Olam). It is highly relevant for understanding the practical, ethical, and transformative dimensions of modern Kabbalah as applied to human society and individual spiritual evolution.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience primarily consists of students and practitioners of Kabbalah, particularly those within the Ashlag lineage or seeking a deeper understanding of its practical applications. It also appeals to individuals interested in esoteric philosophy, spiritual ethics, global peace studies, and the underlying spiritual causes of societal dysfunction. The text requires a willingness to engage with abstract philosophical arguments and a contemplative approach to self and society, positioning it for serious spiritual seekers and academic researchers of Western Esotericism.
